    HTML Panel Tips #20: Javascript Frameworks

    Javascript definitely has a problem: too many frameworks! But as my Color Correction maestro Dan Margulis would put it: ‚Äúthe opposite problem might be much worse‚Äù. I‚Äôve tackled the issue of JS frameworks in a dedicated chapter of my Photoshop HTML Panels Development course, but I‚Äôd like to add some new thoughts here as well.

    This is an atypical Tip:¬†the topic needs more than a quick coverage so bear with me and read along. Also, note that I‚Äôm not, strictly speaking, a front-end JS expert: I know how to put together some stuff, but I‚Äôm not really into Webpack, Babel, EcmaScript 2015, etc. so I‚Äôve a pragmatic approach. Coming from Flash Panels and the Olav Kvern school of blogposts, I‚Äôve been using MVC patterns in ActionScript; like many others, I‚Äôve found myself stuck in a dead end when wind changed and turned to HTML. As Matthias Petter Johansson predicts in an entertaining video appropriately called¬†Too many tools and frameworks¬†I chose my framework based on the combination of Popularity (how much it is widespread and adopted) and Authority (who‚Äôs build it) ‚Äì you can‚Äôt fail this way, can you? So I went with Google AngularJS.

    AngularJS

    Being a self-taught JS developer, the framework¬†learning curve was¬†quite steep: so I bought courses, books etc. and started climbing mount Angular. I‚Äôve used it in some of my commercial products and, as I‚Äôve mentioned, I‚Äôve also built a dedicated demo panel in AngularJS for my Photoshop HTML Panels Development course. Per se, that Panel is not rocket science: it scans your PS open document and seeks for Text layers, retrieving the text content and letting you update it. It features three tabs (just a pretext to use routing) and looks like that:

    Yet I‚Äôve built it in AngularJS trying to use all the best practices I knew: separation of concerns, modularity, you name it. I ended up with a code by all means exaggerated for that little panel, but which architecture can scale and support much more complex and elaborated projects. You can have a look at the dependencies schema used in this image.

    If you‚Äôre familiar with AngularJS you can understand what‚Äôs in there ‚Äì I won‚Äôt get through it in this very post: the full Panel‚Äôs code, with detailed explanations, is available for download alongside in a¬†28 custom made panels¬†bundle with the¬†Panels course¬†‚Äì you can borrow it and use it in your own projects if you want.

    Now, after having written that chapter, I ended up using¬†the very same architecture in an actual, commercial product: a contract job for a Panel that looks apparently simple (but it‚Äôs not üò∂). Compared to other jobs I did in the past, this one features a great amount of modularity: possibly it wasn‚Äôt totally needed when I build it, but being a contract job I‚Äôve preferred to overdo when coding¬†it, and then ensure hopefully easier updates in the future. As a compulsive¬†new technologies addicted, I have now to face the advent of AngularJS v2, which scrambles all the rules of v1 and is an entirely different beast. Mind you, I went with Angular from the beginning¬†mostly because I like learning new stuff, and for¬†knowing a framework such as AngularJS might¬†be useful for my career apart from HTML Panels (wishful thinking).

    Mind you, I can¬†stay with v1 for a long long time! Stuff evolves so rapidly in JS land that by the time Angular v1 is¬†ultimately unsupported, new players will¬†have hit the field: so basically‚Ä¶ why bother now (besides, Adobe isn‚Äôt the fastest company¬†in updating SDK). Also, I‚Äôm not a full-time developer and another steep learning curve will eat time that (a) I don‚Äôt have, and (b) that I can spend more profitably, i.e. writing another book. Angular v2 is better experienced using TypeScript ‚Äì I can barely stand CoffeeScript as a language to compile to JS, I‚Äôm sorry but another strongly typed language is not in my plans. So‚Ä¶ I‚Äôve taken the chance to get accustomed to a valid alternative (at least for HTML Panels) that I‚Äôd like to suggest you.

    VueJS

    Let‚Äôs start with downsides: it isn‚Äôt as widespread as AngularJS (note by my future self from 2019: it really is now!!) or the other framework that everybody‚Äôs excited about (React ‚Äì which frankly I don‚Äôt know, but the article ‚ÄúYour Timeline for Learning React‚Äú¬†is enough to make me skip it altogether ‚Äì if you really think I should get into React instead, please let me know in the comments the reason), nonetheless¬†Vue.js has some respectable 20K stars on Github. Another concern may be that Vue.js is a personal project: yes, it‚Äôs mainly built by Evan You, not an enterprise backed developers team. If you can live with that‚Ä¶ Vue.js has:

    • an amazing community: apparently it‚Äôs very popular among¬†Laravel developers
    • very good documentation: IMHO uber-important factor¬†when choosing a framework
    • reactive data binding: rendered templates are always up-to-date
    • components
    • routing

    and much more, that I won‚Äôt cover here¬†‚Äôcause frankly I can‚Äôt understand it yet ‚Äì I‚Äôve just started approaching the framework‚Ä¶ How sad is truth, isn‚Äôt it?! Vue.js implements¬†a MVVM (Model - View - ViewModel) pattern, which is considered a good choice for user interfaces (like‚Ä¶¬†Panels!).

    One of the most¬†understandable articles on MVVM is by Addy Osmani, and I don‚Äôt know why, this doesn‚Äôt surprise me. Let‚Äôs have a look at a dead simple example: In this case, the View is the templating in the HTML, the Model is the model¬†object (a regular, plain JS object) and the ViewModel is the Vue instance that binds the View (here the "app" element ‚Äì think about it as¬†the Vue‚Äôs version of Angular ng-app), and binds the Model.

    Reactivity means that there‚Äôs no need to update the view if/when the model changes ‚Äì as soon as model is updated, the view will reflect the new value. This leads to two-way data binding, such as: Here you see v-model (equivalent to Angular ng-model) and the use of a JSON filter with $data. Refactoring the same example with modular ViewModel (usually called just vm) you can see that it‚Äôs really the data that drives everything, so if you need two Vue instances ‚Äì and their parent ‚Äì to share the same model, just share it by identity: In the above example, the globalModel¬†var contains reactive data that is used¬†by both vmRadius and vmOpacity. Extending further the idea, each vm can bind model data that is both shared and private, like: If you need it, you can always use a PubSub pattern with $on, $emit and $broadcast, similarly to Angular.

    Vue.js¬†also has all the directive that you‚Äôre used to in Angular, so¬†v-if, v-show, v-for, v-on, etc. I haven‚Äôt talked about methods (i.e. functions that you define in the vm), but I‚Äôm not really writing a Vue tutorial here ‚Äì the official documentation is remarkably good and there‚Äôs also this videoseries (mostly free) by the always great Jeffrey Way ‚Äì let me just briefly mention components: Everything I‚Äôve shown here is really basic, there‚Äôs so much more to discover in Vue.js! Hopefully I‚Äôve raised to your attention what seems to me a valuable alternative to more known and opinionated frameworks that, in the context of HTML Panels, for some among us are either overkill and/or difficult to master and maintain.
